mil5.2.6:0.1_0: The Simile of the Making Hand
mil5.2.6:1.1_0: “Even when you speak with a dragon,
mil5.2.6:1.2_0: ‘Someone who kills living creatures makes much bad karma.’
mil5.2.6:1.3_0: Furthermore, the Buddha has lied to the textual analysis of the Monastic Law:
mil5.2.6:1.5_0: If he kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, and uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical, that’s wrong for that, wrong no offense.
mil5.2.6:1.6_0: if he makes any effort with that body, in that he acts wrongly toward his father; he himself has made much demerit; he acts wrongly toward him;
mil5.2.6:1.7_0: This is a sarong that is hard to get, and you should follow right behind someone else who is hardwood.”
mil5.2.6:2.1_0: “Great king, since he does not know that the Buddha has killed living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, and lie down on his way.
mil5.2.6:2.2_0: When the Buddha had spoken this, he spoke to the Monastic Law:
mil5.2.6:2.4_0: there is the meaning of the teaching.
mil5.2.6:2.6_0: There is, great king, who attains, has, and is an offense of wrong conduct.
mil5.2.6:2.7_0: The exposition of the teaching on the simile of the class of offenses that the Buddha spoke to him about
mil5.2.6:2.8_0: ‘There’s no offense for one who doesn’t know.’”
mil5.2.6:2.9_0: “It’s good, Sir, that you should repeat what I have said.”
